instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1932: What is A1932? A1932 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Late 2018, 2019 with EMC 3184, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01521..
definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PPVCCSA_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCSA_S0_CPU? Main power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. This is NOT shorted to ground if it has a low resistance â€“ this is a common mistake people make. A chip that requires high power at a low voltage like a CPU or GPU will have a low measured resistance to ground..
definitions.PP5V_S5_LDO: What is PP5V_S5_LDO? PP5V_S5_LDO is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a S5 soft off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3S: What is PP3V3_G3S? PP3V3_G3S is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in a G3S standby state. .
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.

threads.title: macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, no power
threads.message:
Hi, i have a macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, no power, restor t2 ok no problem but no display or boot on the macbook, no liquid damage, very clean, no short, I changed <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and always the same result: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12V66 stable but low and <SIGNAL>CHGR_BGATE</SIGNAL> not stable 12V66 at 0V20, I removed F7000 and F8400 to measure but same result.
Do you have an idea please ? Thanks

measures
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>              3V3
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL>        12V66
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>       3V3
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>              3V3
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>           20V4
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>                5V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL>          5V
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P5VG3S</SIGNAL> 12V66
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S</SIGNAL>             3V3
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3SSW_SNS</SIGNAL>  0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL>              1V8
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>         0V
<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>     0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>         1V8
<SIGNAL>CHGR_BGATE</SIGNAL>       12V3and0V20 the voltage oscillates
<SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H</SIGNAL>       12V3and0V20 the voltage oscillates

trackpad click, no sound, no display, but restore t2 ok
charger plugged in 20v2 and 1a07

ps: sorry for my english i translate by google, i am french

threads.title: macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, no power
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12V66 stable but low"
Low what?
Voltage is correct!

This board should boot without battery connected.
However, fan will spin to max and system gets very slow.
You need first to get correct voltages for the big coils.

"I removed F7000 and F8400"
Why?
These coils are not related in any way.
F7000 is for battery, not for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>!

Test the board alone on the desk; nothing connected, apart of charger.
Check if you get voltage on big coils; like L8100/02, L7290...

threads.title: macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, no power

I put back f7000 f8400.

L7210 L7430 L7410 = 0V

threads.title: macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, no power
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground on the big coils.
Switch to ohm scale for CPU ones; as usual for less than 010 readings on diode mode.

threads.title: macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, no power
threads.message:
I said to use ohm scale ONLY for very low readings in diode mode.
K/Mohm readings are not so useful as you think.
And I hope you will correctly check in diode mode (red probe on ground).

Post <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> voltages.

threads.title: macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, no power
threads.message:
You cannot expect <SIGNAL>1V2_S3</SIGNAL>, if <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> doesn't even get enable signal.
0.45V made me think something might be wrong with the chip itself; seems not.

Check if <SIGNAL>PCH_RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is present.
Also trigger <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> (SWE010) and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PCH_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).

threads.title: macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PCH_RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3v
<SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> 3v28
<SIGNAL>PCH_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> 3v3 for two seconds when GND et <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> are connected

threads.title: macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, no power
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PCH_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> 3v3 for two seconds when GND et <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> are connected"
You should note 3V-0V-3V when trigger <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>; must stay at 3V in the rest of time.

threads.title: macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, no power
threads.message:
it's very difficult to get it, but when I get there it goes from 3v3 to 0v without going back to 3v3

sometimes I get 0v5 1v2 but it goes back to 0v and stays at 0v

threads.title: macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, no power
threads.message:
Once <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is released, <SIGNAL>PCH_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> must go back to 3V.

To make your job easy, solder an wire on a convenient point of <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> line; like pin 2 of SWE001.
Then touch any metal plate, to simulate power button.

threads.message: yes I tried many times, always the same the 3v comes but leaves too early and does not come back once SWE001 is released

threads.message: problem solved, you said true <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> was faulty I replaced it, the macbook works :), Thanks for your help
